intro: Crocodeilanthe chachapoyensis, commonly known as the Chachapoyan fern, is a rare epiphytic fern native to the cloud forests of northern Peru. It belongs to the family Polypodiaceae and is characterized by its intricate, lace-like fronds that are often adorned with tiny, spore-producing structures called sori. The plant thrives in humid, shaded environments and relies on its ability to absorb moisture and nutrients from the air and surrounding substrates. Its unique morphology and restricted habitat make it a subject of interest for botanists studying tropical flora. Conservation efforts are crucial due to its vulnerability to habitat loss and environmental changes.
